key_points: Advocates are seeking justice for Chrystul Kizer, a teen who killed her sex trafficker, comparing her case to Kyle Rittenhouse's recent acquittal.
Kizer, who was 17 at the time of the killing, is accused of murdering Randall Volar, a man awaiting trial for human trafficking.
Kizer asserts she acted in self-defense and is awaiting trial, while facing multiple felony charges including first-degree intentional homicide.
Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted earlier this month, his defense argued he acted in self-defense during a Black Lives Matter protest in Kenosha.
During the protest, Rittenhouse killed two men; he was found not guilty on all charges.
Advocates for Kizer argue her case deserves similar consideration to Rittenhouse, emphasizing the self-defense claim.
Demonstrations were held in Kenosha to protest Rittenhouse's verdict and to bring attention to Kizer's case.
An appeals court has allowed Kizer the right to use the 'affirmative' defense, arguing her actions were a direct result of being trafficked.
The State Supreme Court is reviewing whether Kizer can use this defense in her trial.
Chrystul Kizer was released on bond in 2020 after community groups raised $400,000; Rittenhouse's bond was $2 million, also raised by supporters.
